content: I don't got anything clever to say rocks we're making rocks though my friends
welcome back to another episode of black magic craft recently I put a poll up on
my patreon page where I asked my patreon supporters to vote for what they would
like to be seen made in a tutorial this month and this video is not their number
one choice their number one choice was actually the thing I really wanted to do
and because it's something I really want to do I'm spending a bit of extra time
developing the technique until I get it really right and I'm really happy with
it before I make the videos curious what that project is well you will have to
either stay tuned until this video is made or head on over to patreon and
support black magic crafts there where you get an inside look at all these
interesting behind-the-scenes things that being said this video is their
number two choice because as it just so happens the runner-up was rocks
specifically rocks with alternative texturing and coloring techniques and
coincidentally in the last episode I made a very simple Little Rock sculpture
to demonstrate the technique on I unsurprisingly got a lot of people
asking how I carved or sculpted this piece so runner-up project and answering
the question of how did I make this in this video this week I'm going to be
showing you one of many methods that you can use for sculpting large rocks to use
in your games now this is one of those types of projects that there's no one
way to do it there are so many different ways that you can sculpt the rocks
texture than paint them I'm just going to show you some of the techniques I use
and you can take them and mix them and add your own take on it do whatever you
want this is a pretty easy project to do and
it doesn't use a lot of you know expense material real simple real cheap if
you're just starting out and you're having trouble or a little bit
intimidated with what to buy for this or other projects head over to Blackmagic
craft CA there I have a web store where I link to all the different products and
tools that I use regularly this is my Amazon affiliate store so all the
purchases that you guys make through there I get a small commission from
Amazon and that helps fund this channel it's actually a great way that you guys
can financially support Blackmagic craft without actually spending any extra
money to do it just buy stuff that you're going to buy anyway just do it
through this so grab your phone and let's build some
rocks for this project you are going to need some styrofoam preferably XPS
insulation foam if you can get your hands on it
but if not if you're one of those people who unfortunately them have access to
XPS foam this is something that you can actually do with the expanded
polystyrene that you get from like packing material and whatnot
and you're going to want the foam to be fairly thick here this chunk is three
inches thick and as you can tell it is actually just two layers of inch and a
half glued together because more than likely you're not going to be able to
find XPS this thick so what you can do is take a bunch of scrap material it
doesn't matter what the thickness is and glue it together you can use a few
layers of half-inch one-inch whatever you got use up your cut-offs this is a
great way to use up the garbage and to glue these together all you need to do
is take some white PVA glue and brush on a solid coating on one surface press
another one on top and leave some weight on it to dry now a word of caution this
will need longer to dry than you probably expect
I've left a batch of them to dry overnight and as I started working with
it they actually still are not totally dry they'll be dry around the edges but
in the center there may still be some uncured glue because this insulation
foam is non-porous and it's like like vapor tight so it takes a long time for
the in the middle to dry if you can leave
them sit for a couple days if possible if not what you can do is actually put
some toothpicks through to stop the two pieces from sliding around when you
start curving anyway we're going to carve these up you can get away with
just carving these up with Olfa knife like I always use but if you have a
proxxon or even a handheld hot wire cutter like this they the hot wire is
going to give you a big head start on the carving process so what I like to do
is carve out a basic shape that I want this rock to be and I try to carve it
bigger than I expect to want the finished product to be because in the
next step it kind of gets broken down and it gets a little bit smaller so if
you have a stalks on and turn the thing on and you're going to crank the heat
right up to you know five or six so this wire is really hot so it gets through
this you know six three inch foam and you can see just how easily this thing
slices through thick foam even with a layer of glue in between so I'm just
carving out a rough kind of shape and that's that now the really satisfying
part I don't know why but I always really enjoy doing that so when I make
my rocks I am NOT going for ultra realism I am going for playability and
something that has a nice nice aesthetic so when I do these I always leave the
top surface flat and not you know carved because I want a place to be able to put
minis I'm not doing very realistic wargaming this is I play D&D as I'm sure
most of you guys do or similar games so try to keep playability in mind when
you're making these so from this basic shape we
want to start carving out some more variants and quickly you can do that
again is with a hot wire and just going in at different angles and making some
different layered cuts and this is why I said make the piece a little bit bigger
than you expect what you want the finished product to be because this
stage and the next stage starts removing quite a bit more material and here I'm
just really trying to give some variance and depth to the piece and I'll come in
with the wire at different angles you could at this point with just a quick
hot wire carving call this thing done and I have a whole bunch of rocks that I
use that are carved pretty much just like this and I like the look of it but
from the last basics episode people were asking me how I carved this little piece
that I used to demonstrate dry brushing and on this one I took this technique
and did one more thing to get these more natural cuts so let's move over and I'll
show you how we did that so at this point if you are noticing that your
pieces might still have some wet glue and are sliding around a little bit
because you're impatient like me taking toothpicks now that you got your basic
shape and poked a couple through the bottom and this will just help them to
not slide around if there's still any white glue in order to give this a kind
of more broken up look rather than this kind of sharp glacial kind of carving
it's really simple take your finger and start breaking it
that's it that's how you get these little natural divots so just go around
and start pulling chunks off and when you're left with little piece flaps like
this that don't quite break you want to make sure you remove those because they
look a little bit strange and there is no science to this you just have to kind
of work with it until you like the look you can be as aggressive with this as
you would like and again you can see I'm losing a lot of material here making
this don't smaller which is why you want to oversize it before you get to this
point now I will say that if you are going to use this technique it is a good
idea to kind of go around and do it on most of the piece because you just have
a few chunks ripped out like this and then the rest is this kind of clean
smooth cut it looks a little bit weird so once you do this you're kind of
committed to doing the entire piece I'm just going to go around and complete
this whole thing and I'll show you the next step when I'm done so when you're
done going around and ripping out chunks you're going to be left with something
kind of like this and again you're going to have to just experiment and you know
mess around with it till you get it to a point where you like the look and
there's no real rule as to what's right and what's wrong because this now has a
whole bunch of little thin points on it and it's styrofoam it's pretty soft and
vulnerable and I don't think the Mod Podge coat that I usually do is enough
to make these really hard so I actually like to give these two coatings first I
like to coat them in some kind of all-purpose drywall joint compound and
this is going to make them really hard but it's also going to give them some
interesting texture and if you have this seam line and you want to hide it which
again is a personal preference this is going to do that so I just take some of
this straight out of the pail on the finger and start slathering it on now I
don't care about how even or smooth this goes on initially I just try to make
sure that I have enough on the joint lines where I want to hide it and we're
going to come back in and smooth this out after so just go around and give
everything a messy coat so once you have your Rock mostly covered with this joint
compound you're going to take some water just your paint water cup and this kind
of big crappy brush that I told you to save for something in the basics video
about brushes I'm going to take this brush and some water and you're just
going to start slathering and spreading this joint compound around on the piece
and this can get a little bit messy if you are too aggressive with it it will
fling little blobs of you know joint compound everywhere so you have anything
on your desk that you don't want to get joint compound on move it or just be
cautious so on this first pass I'm mostly just going around and trying to
wet all the stuff that I put on with my finger and try to spread it onto as much
of the piece as possible when you don't have to get like 100% perfect coverage
just most of it this part is especially important if you're not using extruded
polystyrene if you're using the bubbly EPS stuff from packing material because
this will kind of lock in all those little bubbles and prevent them from
falling off in the future so once you have this kind of spread around on most
of the piece you can actually take this brush and start doing some streaks all
in one direction and what this is going to do
is it's actually going to leave a bunch of texture lines a bunch of little
striations that will kind of mimic you know rock that has a lot of thin layers
making it up and it's also going to create another texture for your dry
brushing to pick up when you are doing the paint and since this is you know a
natural piece you don't have to go for perfection you just got to go with
something that you know does the job and once you're done kind of handling it
I like to take a little bit more plaster and just add some texture to the top of
the piece just so that the flat top isn't quite so smooth and then you can
just leave this to dry put it next to a heater or use a blow dryer or just leave
it for you know a couple hours before moving on to the next step once the
drywall joint compound is completely dry it's still important to give your pieces
a coat of Mod Podge and I use the matte Mod Podge mixed with black paint that I
usually use and the reason you still need to do this one is because it will
add another layer of durability and hardness make these really strong but
most importantly the joint compound is very water soluble so even once it's dry
if it gets any water it will rehydrate and start to smear or rub off and that
could happen with the paint that especially could happen if you start
putting washes on this stuff so the Mod Podge will encase and lock that all in
and together they will make a very strong piece there are many different
painting styles that you can use on rock there are so many different colors and
tones and styles of rocks in nature you can definitely get away with just doing
a coat of dark gray than a dry brush of light gray and then a final dry brush of
white just kind of like I showed in the dry brushing episode but here I'm going
to do a little bit more involved of a paint scheme to give things a little bit
more depth and give you guys some ideas but I'm still going to stay in the
territory of of gray rock and I'm not going to venture into you know kind of
sand tones or the kind of more red earthy kind of stuff I'm still going to
be in the gray sort of look just a little bit more involved
so the first code I'm going to do I'm just going to use my cheap craft Mart
acrylic dark gray and on this coat I'm pretty much going to cover the entire
piece I have a damp brush and I'm going to go in and just start coating the
whole thing I'm making sure that I actually get in all the little nooks and
crannies I don't really want any black showing through and you can already see
just with a coat of gray it's already looking pretty good and you could
actually just drop it on the table like that if you don't have time to do and
involve paint job but going to let this dry and come back for the next step so
now that the first layer of gray is dry can start going and building up some
color and this is where you can go from your dark gray coat into a lighter gray
but to make this a little bit more interesting and a little bit more
realistic I'm going to take the gray mix it with some tan and a little bit of
yellow the yellow is important because natural stone tends to have quite a bit
of undertones of greens and yellows and they usually aren't just a straight gray
so adding a bit of yellow or green to the mix will enhance your paint job
quite a bit there's no science to this I'm just going to take some gray a
little bit less this tan may be a 1 to 3 ratio say one drop of yellow and whether
or not this is the right amount of each remains to be seen like anything you
need to experiment a bit if this is looking like it's a little bit too
yellow but not extremely too yellow but just a little bit too yellow you're
probably in the right territory it's not going to end up looking that yellow once
it's so here this is going to be a fairly
full coverage dry brushing right there too much paint on my brush I want to
cover a good amount of the stone this isn't just picking up highlights this is
you know like a maybe 50% coverage and I'm leaving the initial dark gray at the
bottom of all the low spots and crevices and it ends up looking something kind of
like that of course don't forget to hit the top and right here already you can
see what a difference adding that little bit of stippled compound texture did to
enhance the look at the top and you can kind of see some of these striation
marks from the compound brush marks starting to show through so that's
looking pretty good now to make things a little bit more interesting I'm going to
take a little bit of burnt sienna not very much I'm going to put it on my
brush here and I'm going to stipple out pretty much all of it and this is going
to be like a dry stipple I'm not dry brushing I'm not trying to hit all the
highlights I'm just trying to add some almost like veins of color to the piece
and this you know again like anything is going to take some experimenting on your
part to you know find out what is working and what isn't working and don't
overdo it you know a little bit goes a long way but do keep in mind that when
you do the next coat it is going to cover up some of it so don't be worried
if it looks like a little bit too much for this step I'm now going to take the
same tan that I used in the mix of the previous step and do a dry brushing of
just it on its own and if you're having any questions or anything about dry
brushing make sure you go watch my basics video on dry brushing because
there's a good chance I try to answer it there so here I'm using the same brush I
haven't cleaned it in between so I get that natural mixing and with this tan
I'm going to start going in and hitting some of the high points and this is
really going to bring it away from the just kind of gray looking rock that you
normally see people doing the tan really makes it look quite a bit more earthy
and I'm applying significantly less of this than I did of the first dry
brushing I have far less on my brush and I'm being a lot less aggressive at this
point now in spots you can really see those brush marks from the plaster
showing through again don't forget the top now I want to move on to an even
lighter dry brushing but still not quite into a white so I'm going to use this
suede it's essentially like a shade lighter of this
and and you could obviously just you know mix some of this tan with some
white to get that but I already have this color and it works pretty good so
here this is going to be again an even lighter more minimal dry brushing than
the previous coat and by moving up in several stages here it makes the dry
brushing seem you know a lot more natural like you have a gradient
essentially of colors rather than you know a dark piece that then just has
some really contrasting highlights this it brings the contrast down a lot and it
makes it seem a lot more realistic I mean this is still far removed from
paper realistic you know stones that you would see in like model railway dioramas
or even what a lot of the war gamers do but I think it's a nice step up from
what you often see on a D&D table and it's like kind of like a nice medium in
between so there we go just a little bit of that tan and then I'm going to
immediately go in with this vanilla or an off-white and do one last highlight
and this is going to be just on the very highest points I'm going to be pretty
careful with this one and this is what's really just going to make the whole
thing glow and now that the PERT siena that I kind
of dabbed on is getting mostly covered it's just kind of peeking through a
little bit and being very subtle and it really adds quite a bit I think to to
the look and I'm going to complete this with some washes so I'm going to make
this a little bit more heavily covered with the white then I would if I wasn't
doing the wash so you have to make that decision beforehand to know how bright
to make this but if you're gonna do a wash you can make it a little bit more
extreme now the fun part the black wash here is the batch that I made up for my
wood tiles that I've saved in this bottle here this is a very simple black
wash made of just water a little bit of dish detergent and some black paint as
well as a few dabs of gray and brown mixed in and I'm just going to go ahead
and coat this whole thing if you are doing a large batch of these stones you
can actually apply your wash in a dip just like I did with my wood tiles you
know set up a deep tub just dunk them and you'll get through them really
really quickly but I'm just doing this one here so it's a little bit easier and
more practical just to brush it on and here's where things get a little bit
interesting I'm going to take some of this black wash not a whole batch of it
and I'm going to take some silver metallic and some kind of coppery bronze
metallic and I am going to put a drop or two of each into this wash and
mix it up and what this is going to do is it's going to take all those little
reflective particles that are in the metallics and I'm going to do one more
wash with this and it's going to add a nice little glistening effect that's
going to make this piece look more like say a granite stone because if you look
at rock it tends to have a lot of little reflective particles in it I don't know
what they are because I'm not a geologist but I know that they are there
and this is a way that you can add that add that to your piece and don't go
overboard with this don't mix in too much just enough so that there's this
nice little reflection in the paint now this is going to have to sit for quite a
while to dry and when it is dry then it can be sealed and it will be ready for
the table and there you have it a fairly simple project a lot of different
options for you guys to work with I hope you found this video useful if you did
hit that like button and drop me a comment below and if you're not already
a subscriber hit that button below and join the black magic craft party lastly
if you really want to help out black magic craft because you love what I'm
doing head on over to my patreon page there you can join up to support black
magic crafts and you can reap all the cool rewards that I have set up for my
supporters and with that happy crafting I'll see you guys again next time Cheers
